content: Legislation to rewrite and reauthorize the Export Administration Act of 1979 (EAA) may be considered in the 111th Congress. Several pieces of legislation in the 110th Congress addressed penalties, enforcement, diversion of goods, and integration of export control data. The EAA controls sensitive dual-use goods and technologies with civilian and military applications, including those that can contribute to the proliferation of weapons. The EAA has been periodically reauthorized since its original expiration in 1989, with the last extension expiring in August 2001. The Export Administration Act of 1979 (EAA) controls dual-use goods and technologies with civilian and military applications. It establishes regulations for exports administered by the Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) under the Department of Commerce. The EAA focuses on regulating exports of civilian goods and technology with military applications, based on strategic relationships and threats to national security. The Export Administration Act of 1979 (EAA) regulates dual-use items with civilian and military applications. There is a debate on whether to liberalize or tighten export controls to balance international competition and national security threats. The act's evolution, major features, and controls authorized are discussed in this report. The report discusses the Export Administration Act's evolution in the 20th century, major features, types of controls, Commerce Control List, and export licensing procedures. It also addresses issues related to maintaining export controls under IEEPA and highlights controlled commodities. Additionally, it explores competing perspectives on contentious themes in the export control debate, such as technology controllability, multilateral control regimes, organization of the export control system, and the impact on the U.S. economy and business. Export controls have been a part of U.S. policy for almost a century, with a shift towards extensive peacetime efforts after WWII. The Export Control Act of 1949 was enacted in response to the new security threat posed by the Soviet-Bloc countries during the Cold War. It identified three reasons for imposing export controls: short-supply controls to prevent the export of scarce goods, foreign policy controls to promote U.S. foreign policy, and controls related to regional stability, human rights, anti-terrorism, missile technology, and chemical and biological warfare. The Export Control Act of 1949 established national security controls to restrict the export of goods and technology that could enhance the military capability of countries threatening the United States. A multilateral control regime involving NATO allies was also established, leading to the creation of the Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls (CoCom) in 1949. The Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls (CoCom) was established in 1949 to regulate exports among NATO allies. The Export Control Act was renewed multiple times with high restrictions until the 1960s when pressure for liberalization led to the passing of the Export Administration Act of 1969. The Export Administration Act of 1969 replaced the restrictive Export Control Act of 1949, with further revisions in 1974, 1977, and 1979. Amendments in 1985 led to some liberalization. The collapse of the Soviet Union in 1989 marked a shift in U.S. export control policy. Despite streamlining, the basic structure of the law remains intact, with calls for revamping to enhance exports. The Export Administration Act of 1969 replaced the Export Control Act of 1949, with revisions in subsequent years. Despite streamlining, calls for revamping persist to enhance exports and address national security threats. The dissolution of CoCom in 1994 and the establishment of the Wassenaar Arrangement in 1997 significantly changed the export control landscape. Congress has struggled to agree on reforms since the 101st Congress. The Export Administration Act has faced challenges in Congress for reform since the 101st Congress. Temporary extensions and Executive Orders have been used to continue export controls. Legislation in 2000 extended the EAA of 1979 until August 20, 2001. Legislation passed in 2000 extended the Export Administration Act of 1979 until August 20, 2001, temporarily removing the need to operate the export control system under IEEPA powers. Export control authority has since been operating under IEEPA provisions pursuant to Executive Order 13222. Legislation to rewrite the Export Administration Act has been introduced in recent Congresses. In the 106th and 107th Congresses, export control legislation was introduced but faced challenges in the Senate due to concerns about national security impact. Senator Enzi introduced bills in both Congresses, with hearings held and favorable reports, but no further action was taken. In the 107th Congress, the Export Administration Act (EAA) was introduced and debated in the Senate and House committees. The Senate passed the bill with amendments, while the House version, H.R. 2581, included provisions related to oversight of nuclear transfers to North Korea. In the 107th Congress, H.R. 2581, related to oversight of nuclear transfers to North Korea, was passed by the House International Relations Committee with 35 amendments. The House Armed Services Committee further amended and reported the legislation, but it received no further consideration in the 107th Congress. In the 108th Congress, Representative Dreier introduced EAA legislation (H.R. 55), identical to S. 149, but no action was taken on it. The National Defense Authorization Act has also been used to attempt to amend the export control regime. The National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) has been used to attempt to amend the export control regime. In 2004, the House version of NDAA 2005 (H.R. 4200) contained provisions related to dual-use export controls, requiring licenses for certain technologies and items. The House NDAA report expressed concern about potential military embargoes on China and the transfer of U.S. goods or technology. A bill to revise the Export Administration Act was introduced in the 109th Congress but was not comprehensive. The Export Administration Act revision bill introduced in the 109th Congress addressed penalties, enforcement, and U.S. relations with multilateral control regimes. It aimed to extend the expired EAA for two years and provide authorization for export control activities. However, the bill did not receive consideration in the 109th Congress, and no comprehensive legislation was introduced in the 110th Congress. Legislation introduced in Congress aimed to amend enforcement and penalties under the Export Administration Act, integrate export control information into electronic filing, and target countries of diversion concern. Only one bill, S. 3445/H.R. 7112, was acted upon in the 110th Congress, with H.R. 7112 passing in the House. H.R. 7112 was introduced and passed in the House under suspension of the rules on September 26, 2008. Representative Sherman introduced the Export Control Improvements Act (H.R. 3515) on July 31, 2009, which includes provisions on export controls enforcement, integration of export control data in the AES, and diversion control. The legislation grants additional enforcement authority for the Export Administration Regulations during the lapse of the EAA under the IEEPA. The draft legislation grants investigative authority to departments and agencies under the EAR for conducting investigations in the US and abroad. It allows for search, detention, and seizure of goods by Commerce within the US and at ports of entry or exit. The bill also directs the Secretary of Commerce to publish guidelines for export control compliance programs and includes provisions for undercover investigations and audits. The bill includes new language governing the use of funds for undercover investigations and operations, establishing audit and reporting requirements. Title 1 of H.R. 3515 integrates licensing requirements, embargoes, and data collection rules into the Automated Export System to prevent improper shipments. The issue of evasion of U.S. export controls through transhipment hubs remains a concern for Congress. The 111th Congress is concerned about evasion of U.S. export controls through transhipment hubs, particularly in the United Arab Emirates. In 2006, computer circuits were diverted to Iran for bomb detonators from the UAE. The Bureau of Industry and Security proposed creating a 'Country Category C' for countries of diversion concern, but no country was designated as such. H.R. 3515 would legislate the 'Category C' concept with regards to diversion to Iran, requiring the President to identify countries of concern within 180 days. Countries could be designated as possible diversion concerns or diversion concerns, with measures in place to strengthen export control systems and address non-compliance. The legislation would require the Administration to designate countries as Destinations of Diversion Concern if improvements are not seen within 12 months. Countries directly involved in transhipments, reexportations, or diversions would be listed as countries of diversion concern, facing additional licensing requirements and increased end-user checks. An annual report on transfers of dual-use U.S. technology to concerning countries and entities would also be mandated. President Obama initiated a review of the U.S. export control system in 2009. The U.S. export control system is under review by the National Security Council and the National Economic Council. Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates proposed a 4-pronged approach to reform the system, including creating a single licensing agency, adopting a unified control list, implementing an integrated information technology system, and establishing a single enforcement coordination agency. These changes would be implemented in three phases. The administration's blueprint for reforming the U.S. export control system includes creating a single enforcement coordination agency and harmonizing the Commerce Control List with the U.S. Munitions List in three phases. The first phase involves preparatory work to establish a tiered control structure, standardized licensing processes, and an "Enforcement Fusion Center." Phase II would implement a harmonized licensing system with two identically structured tiered control lists, aiming to reduce license requirements significantly. The White House fact sheet outlines plans to harmonize and tier control lists, leading to a significant reduction in license requirements. The proposal includes moving items from the munitions list to the dual-use list, examining unilateral controls, and consulting with multilateral partners. Phase III will see the debut of a new export control system with a single licensing agency, merged control lists, a Primary Enforcement Coordination Agency, and a unified IT system for licensing and enforcement. The 3-phase plan for a new export control system includes harmonizing control lists, reducing license requirements, and creating a single licensing agency. Secretary Gates predicts the plan will unfold over the next year, but many questions remain unanswered about legislative actions needed for changes to control lists and agency structure. The proposed changes in export control legislation include creating a new licensing agency, with the placement within existing departments or as an independent entity still undecided.
